Title: Get Involved
Content:
Caregivers across Washington and Montana are joining together with their local communities to talk about how we can work together to make our Union stronger. Here are a few ways you can get involved:

ADVOCATES 

Advocates are important for our caregivers who work in agencies and nursing homes. They provide a voice for all the caregivers they work with and are the people their coworkers trust to help them if issues arise at work. Advocates also know how to contact our Union staff and officers when necessary. Being an advocate means enforcing members’ rights within our Union contract and representing coworkers in investigatory and disciplinary meetings with supervisors. 

HOME ACTIVIST

Because of our current environment, our Union has to be creative about how we engage with members. Social media leaders take action on social media with provided tools to connect with and help inform caregivers, friends, and families about issues that matter the most to us. Together, we lead statewide campaigns to help demonstrate to lawmakers that caregivers and caregiving is essential and should be respected and treated as such. Attend a monthly meeting to learn more. 

ENGAGE MEMBERS

Member-to-Member Specialists (MMS) are caregivers who take a break from our regular caregiving work. We spend our days calling other caregivers on the telephone to talk with them about what it means to be in a Union together, how they can get involved, and why it’s so important that we all stick together. It’s a great opportunity to do something different for a little while and develop new skills. But the most exciting, inspirational part of this job is getting to talk with other caregivers about what our Union can do and hear from them about how they want to shape the future of our Union.

RECRUIT NEW MEMBERS

As a recruiter, you’d get to talk to new caregivers about what the Union is and why it’s so important for us to stand together! We’re looking for caregivers who want to connect with other caregivers in your area, welcome them to our community, and make a difference for our shared future. Each conversation you’d be having with caregivers is about 15 to 30 minutes during a caregiver’s first training and DSHS orientation. Depending on how many people can help in your area, you may be asked to help as little as once a month or as much as a couple of times a week.

JOIN LOCAL MEETINGS 

Watch for invitations from your organizer to upcoming events and meetings where caregivers in your area come together to discuss Union wins, share stories, and more! Make sure your contact information is correct by completing the membership form at join775.org. 

If you’d like more information about getting involved, please call our Member Resource Center at 1-866-371-3200 or email us at mrc@seiu775.org between 8 a.m. and 4:30 p.m., Monday through Friday.

Title: IPOne's Electronic Visitation Verification (EVV)
Content:
We’re holding DSHS accountable for pay and damages!

IPOne’s Electronic Visitation Verification (EVV) system has resulted in hundreds of caregivers like you receiving incomplete pay for hours worked and miles driven.

IPOne’s EVV app has failed to work for many of us, and even though we fought for and won alternate ways to submit hours, those options are often inaccessible or subject to system errors. 

This FAQ is available in:

  • Korean: 추가 자료
  • Russian: EVV: Часто задаваемые вопросы
  • Simplified Chinese: 电子访问验证
  • Spanish: Preguntas frecuentes sobre la EVV
  • Vietnamese: Câu Hỏi Thường Gặp Về EVV

775 CAMPAIGNS

We’re holding DSHS accountable for pay and damages!

IPOne’s Electronic Visitation Verification (EVV) system has resulted in hundreds of caregivers like you receiving incomplete pay for hours worked and miles driven. IPOne’s EVV app has failed to work for many of us, and even though we fought for and won alternate ways to submit hours, those options are often inaccessible or subject to system errors. 

If your paycheck was short any hours or mileage call the Member Resource Center at 1 (866) 371-3200 to report the issue. We are staffing a specific line for Individual Providers experiencing issues with IPOne’s EVV payroll system - just call the MRC and following the prompts for EVV issues.

Please keep record of:

  • Time spent on hold with IPOne
  • Late fees and charges incurred because of your late or incomplete paycheck

We are working hard to make sure you get paid for the hours you worked. Together, we will hold the State and IPOne accountable to challenges presented by the new IPOne EVV system.  We will keep updating this website with any new developments.

Continuation of health care: The state and the Health Benefits Trust are working to make sure health benefit coverage is extended for anyone who may receive an incorrect payment during IPOne’s transition to their new EVV system.

Hazard Pay not showing up in the IPOne portal: We’ve alerted IPOne to this problem. The state and IPOne have assured us that this is just a delay, and the $2.54 an hour in hazard pay IPs are getting for January-March will appear when payroll runs for January 1-15, which happens at the beginning of February. We recommend you check your paycheck in IPOne's portal. For how to directs see below. Note: Agency home care workers are negotiating new hazard pay rates with their employers for January – March.

As of December 16 2020, by Federal mandate, Washington State caregivers are required to log hours via Electronic Visitation Verification (EVV).

Frequently Asked Questions

What about caregivers who live with their clients?

  • Live-In Providers are exempt from EVV AND need to apply for a live-in exemption in the IPOne Portal. The Live-In Exemption goes into effect in the pay period AFTER you apply.
  • To apply, visit IPOne's how to guide

Why is EVV happening?

  • The 21st Century Cures Act passed by Congress set new rules requiring states to use an Electronic Visitation Verification (EVV) system to ensure services paid for by the state are provided to the clients who need them. This applies to all Home and Community-based care services. All non-live in IPs must follow the new rules in order to provide services for their clients.
  • If the state doesn’t implement the federally required EVV, we could lose federal Medicaid funding.

What has our Union done protect our rights during this transition?

  • An exemption for live-in caregivers.
  • Privacy measures to protect your personal information and data.
  • We fought for and won flexibility in reporting for providers without smart phones. If you don’t have a smartphone you will be able to use a phone at your client’s home to log your hours if needed.
  • Guaranteed methods to submit your timesheet if the EVV system fails to work or breaks down.

What do I have to do?

  • Live-In Providers are exempt from EVV but will need to opt for live-in exemption in the IPOne Portal. For detailed instructions on opting for Live-In Exemption, read more here.
  • All non-live in IPs will be expected to log hours via the Time4Care app on a smartphone or tablet or using their client’s registered landline phone.
  • You’ll need to download the Time4Care mobile app (from the App Store for iPhone, or Google Play for Android) to your phone or tablet. This will be the easiest way for you to manage reporting hours.
  • You will use your IPOne username and password to log in to Time4Care.
  • If you don’t have a tablet or smartphone you may also report hours by calling the Hours reporting hotline provided by IPOne. We recommend using the app if possible.

Follow this checklist to transition to EVV if you have not yet done so:

  • Update info in IPOne
    • Set your preferred language so you get the correct materials
    • Input your client’s phone number in case of future EVV use
    • Update your phone and email to stay up to date
    • Live-In Providers: Opt for Live-In Exemption in the IPOne portal
  • Download Time4Care App (from the App Store for iPhone, or Google Play for Android)
  • Enable GPS on phone or tablet
  • Watch videos on how to use Time4Care

How to check your hours

  1. Go to ipone.publicpartnerships.com 
  2. Log in with your current user ID and password, if you don’t have an IPOne Web Portal account, create one by clicking “Sign Up” 

3. Click “Timesheets” on the top of the page 

4. Change the “Timesheet Status” to “All” 

5. Fill “Timesheet Start Date Range” for the earnings period. For example, Dec 16, 2020 – Dec 31, 2020 

6. Click “Search”  

7. Click the link under “Check Number” to download and view that earning statement

Title: COVID-19 Resources
Content:
SEIU 775 and SEIU 775 Benefits Group Resources

Our Union’s actions to respond to the COVID-19 crisis: Learn about the what our Union has been doing to support caregivers though this crisis.

SEIU 775 in the News: Read about what caregivers are doing and how the COVID-19 outbreak is affecting us.

Share your story: Tell us how COVID-19 is impacting you.

Access to COVID-19 Testing and Health Benefits: Learn more information from SEIU 775 Benefits Group.

HCA Certification Exam Rescheduling: Learn more information from SEIU 775 Benefits Group.

Training Information and Updates for Caregivers: Learn more information from SEIU 775 Benefits Group.

Lost Hours

Apply for Unemployment Insurance, Workers’ Comp/L&I, Paid Family Leave Act, or use PTO:

  • Workers’ Compensation Coverage and COVID-19 FAQ – Washington State Department of Labor & Industries
  • Information for workers and businesses affected by COVID-19 – Washington State Employment Security Department
  • Financial Resources for Washington Residents Impacted by COVID-19 – Washington State Department of Financial Institutions
  • If you are interested in getting hours with a new client, you can also sign up with Carina.

IPs: Order PPE

Since the start of the COVID-19 pandemic, we’ve demanded the State provide PPE for all home care workers to protect us and the people we serve. Individual Providers (IPs) can order free PPE once a month, including surgical masks, cloth face coverings, and face shields. If your client is confirmed as COVID-positive or is showing COVID-related symptoms you should immediately request more PPE.

How to order PPE:

  1. Online: Go to research.net/r/RequestPPE and fill out the required information (name, address, provider number, and number of clients).
  2. Phone or Email: Contact your local AAA or DDA.  You only need to contact one person in your county, and you can call or send an email. If you are serving a Developmental Disability client, please contact Barb Uehara at pperequest@dshs.wa.gov or 360-407-1593.

When you file a request, the AAA or DDA will place an order on your behalf. Your order will then be verified and shipped to you within 24-72 hours of your request.

Learn more about requesting PPE here.

Tele-health Guidance from DSHS

Click Here

Montana: COVID-19 Resources

Governor Bullock Announces Emergency Rules to Streamline Unemployment Benefits for Workers Impacted by COVID-19:

  • The rules allow a claimant directed by their employer to leave work or not report to work due to COVID-19 to qualify as being temporarily laid off by the employer and eligible for benefits. Workers who must quarantine or who need to take care of a family member due to COVID-19 are also considered temporarily laid off and eligible for benefits.
  • Allows DLI to waive the one week waiting period before typically receiving benefits to ensure Montanans don’t experience a long gap without a paycheck.
  • Montana employers will receive help through these rules. Individual claims will not be chargeable to a specific employer’s account. The rules also include a provision that could extend the time employers have to file wage reports and pay unemployment insurance contributions if the delay is related to COVID-19.

Hazard Pay: Montana caregivers are on the frontlines of the COVID-19 epidemic. We’re demanding that the federal stimulus money goes towards Hazard Pay for home care, DD and nursing home workers. Sign our Hazard Pay petition today! 

Unemployment: COVID-19 Resource Guide for Montana Employers and Employees from the Montana Department of Labor and Industry (L&I)

PPE: SEIU is working on a federal petition to try and get home care and nursing home workers access to Personal Protective Equipment AND to demand the federal government release a stockpile that they have. You can sign the petition here.

Information from the Montana Department of Public Health and Human Services on COVID-19: Resources and contact information for your local health or tribal health departments.

Title: COVID-19 and SEIU 775
Content:
When you’re hearing so much about COVID-19, it can be overwhelming and hard to know what to believe. Below are trusted resources that we will be updating continuously with the latest information, as well as best practices for keeping yourself, your family, and your client healthy.

  • How and Where to get your COVID-19 Vaccine in Washington State
  • How and Where to Get Your COVID-19 Vaccine in Montana
  • How Caregivers Can Order PPE for Free – Thanks to our Union contract!
  • Frequently Asked Questions

  • Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) Resources
  • Fact Sheets (Multilingual)
  • Read our Homecare is Healthcare Report

775 CAMPAIGNS

Frequently Asked Questions about HADit

Hazard Pay:
Question: Are caregivers getting Hazard Pay?

Answer: We fought for and won hazard pay for Washington home care workers. IPs will receive Hazard Pay of $2.41 through December of 2021. Learn more about IP bargaining and Hazard Pay here.  We continue to fight for Hazard Pay for all caregivers. Go to our Contracts page to find your Agency’s latest Hazard Pay information. 

Client Safety:
Question: What do I do if I or my client gets COVID-19 or is exposed to COVID-19?

Answer: This is a big concern of many caregivers. We encourage you to call your/your client’s primary care physician, and contact your client’s case manager if you are an IP or your supervisor if you are an agency provider. The CDC has a resource guide for living with someone or sharing close quarters with someone with coronavirus. Additionally, the Washington State Department of Health has established a call center to address questions from the public – their number is 1-800-525-0127.

Home Care Guidance for Tele-Health from DSHS: View this document for a list of tasks that can now be done by phone or remotely, and which tasks can only be provided in person. If you work for a private home care agency consult with your agency supervisor before doing tasks by phone or remotely.

  • 远程健康家庭护理指导 (中文 – Chinese) | 원격 의료를 위한 가정 간호 지침 (한국어 – Korean) |Руководство по уходу на дому в режиме телемедицины (российский – Russian) |  Guía de atención domiciliaria sobre telemedicina (Español – Spanish) | Hướng Dẫn Chăm Sóc Tại Nhà đối với Dịch Vụ Chăm Sóc Sức Khỏe Từ Xa (Tiểng Việt –  Vietnamese)

COVID-19 Home Health.Home Care Guidelines: This document provides guidance for staff of home care, home health and hospice agencies to use when helping patients around the house or with personal or clinical care.

  • The document is now available in Amharic,  Arabic,  Cambodian,  Chinese,  English,  Spanish,  Korean,  Laotian,  Russian,  Samoan,  Somali,  Tagalog,  Ukrainian and Vietnamese. All versions of the document are available on ALTSA’s COVID-19 Provider Information page.

Health Insurance:
Question: I lost hours due to the coronavirus and I’m worried that I’m going to lose my health insurance – what can I do?

Answer: We have taken action to ensure home care workers who have Union health insurance won’t lose their coverage if their hours go down as a result of COVID-19. Caregivers will need to notify the Health Benefits Trust that their hours dropped below 80 hours per month as a result of COVID-19, and they will be granted a coverage extension. Keep an eye on your email for details from our Health Benefits Trust on how to report that you’ve lost hours and need this coverage extension.

Lost Hours:
Question: I lost hours or lost a client due to the COVID-19 – what can I do?

Answer: Depending on your situation, you can apply for Unemployment Insurance, Worker’s Comp/L&I, Paid Family Leave Act, or use PTO. You can learn more by clicking below – including taking a quiz that can help point you in the direction of the best resource for you. If you are interested in getting hours with a new client, you can also sign up at CarinaCare.com.

  • If you have lost hours due to COVID-19 and aren’t sure what you can do, please take our quiz to find out which benefits you may be eligible for.
  • Tips for Filing an Unemployment Claim – SEIU 775
  • Workers’ Compensation Coverage and COVID-19 FAQ – Washington State Department of Labor & Industries
  • COVID-19 Scenarios & Benefits Available – Washington State Employment Security Department
  • Information for workers and businesses affected by COVID-19 – Washington State Employment Security Department
  • Financial Resources for Washington Residents Impacted by COVID-19 – Washington State Department of Financial Institutions

Vaccine Information:

Question: Do I need insurance to get the vaccine?

Answer: No, the COVID-19 vaccine is free for everyone and no insurance is needed. Vaccination providers cannot charge you for the vaccine, including copays or coinsurance, or deny the vaccine to anyone without health insurance, or who is underinsured or out of network.

Question: Who can get the vaccine now in Washington state?

Answer: Anyone 12 years of age or older is now eligible to get the COVID-19 vaccine.

Question: My client can’t leave home. How do I get the vaccine for them?

Answer: You can request “homebound vaccination services”. To do so:

  • Call the COVID-19 Assistance Hotline at 1-800-525-0127, then press #. Let them know you need “homebound vaccination services”.
  • Complete this form to request homebound vaccination services.
  • Call your local health department (contact information can be found here) and tell them you need “homebound vaccination services”.

Question: How do I know which vaccine I will get?

Answer: You can go to Vaccines.gov to search by a particular brand of vaccine. However, getting any vaccine is the most important. The CDC recommends that we should get any COVID-19 vaccine that is available and not wait for a specific brand.

Question: Do I still need the vaccine if I already had COVID?

Answer: Yes, you should be vaccinated regardless of whether you already had COVID-19. That’s because experts do not yet know how long you are protected from getting sick again after recovering from COVID-19. Even if you have already recovered from COVID-19, it is possible — although rare — that you could be infected with the virus that causes COVID-19 again.

Question: Do I still need to wear a mask if I’ve been vaccinated?

Answer: As the country opens up, the CDC recommends that those of us who work in healthcare settings, like in-home care, continue to wear a mask and follow other COVID-19 precautions while providing care. Read about the recently updated guidance from the CDC here. 


Question: I’m a caregiver, where can I get PPE?

Answer: Together we fought for and won free PPE for caregivers. APs should request PPE through their agencies. For IPs, there are two ways to get yours.

Online – Order PPE online here by filling out the required information (name, address, provider number, and number of clients).

Phone or Email – Contact your local AAA or DDA. You only need to contact one person in your county, and you can call or send an email. If you are serving a Developmental Disability client, please contact Barb Uehara at pperequest@dshs.wa.gov or 360-407-1523.

Question: Can I get COVID-19 from the Vaccine?

Answer: No. There are no live virus particles. While you might feel minor, temporary side effects from the injection, it is impossible to contract the virus from the vaccine.

Question: Will the vaccine cause side effects? If so, how long might they last?

Answer: Some people who get a COVID-19 vaccine will experience side effects, particularly after a second dose. The side effects of the vaccine appear to be minor and temporary. Participants have reported pain at the injection site, fatigue, and occasional fever, headache, or aching muscles and joints. These side effects fade within 1-2 days.

These side effects are actually common with all vaccines: they are a sign that a vaccine is working and triggering an immune response.

Working People:

uestion: With so many people losing hours and jobs, is there anything we can do to help?

Answer: We know that many people that work at closed businesses are out of work. We are joining with SEIU nationally and other unions to demand economic stimulus focused on working people, not big corporations. Among other things, we are calling for meaningful income replacement checks for all, regardless of citizenship or employment status. You can find out more at protectallworkers.org.

Resources:

Gloves: IPs serving Medicaid and state-only-funded clients have access to gloves as part of each client’s health benefits, thanks to our Union contract. To learn how to get them, click here.

  • Additional Resources: How to Obtain Non-Sterile Gloves for Your Personal Caregivers – Washington State Health Care Authority

Delivery of in-home personal care and Adult Day Health services during the COVID-19 outbreak: Please read recommendations by DSHS regarding delivery of in-home personal care services.

Overtime limits to protect parent providers and live-in caregivers: While they are not eliminating the workweek limits across the board, the state has indicated that they are likely to approve temporarily waiving the overtime workweek limits on a case-by-case basis, especially where there is a concern about bringing additional caregivers into a shared living situation in a way that would increase risk of transmitting COVID-19. You can send a letter to your caseworker requesting an Exception to Client Specific Work Week Limit (CSWWL) to be able to exceed your work week limit and provide all of your client’s authorized hours. We have a template you can use here.

If you experience symptoms of, or believe you were exposed to COVID-19, call these hotlines:

  • Washington State Department of Health Coronavirus hotline: 1-800-525-0127 between 6 am and 10 pm
  • King County Coronavirus hotline: 206-477-3977 between 8 am and 7 pm

Find your local Health Department online here  – Washington State Department of Health

Montana Information: Information and resources for Montanans is available here.

SEIU 775 and SEIU 775 Benefits Group Resources

How to get Vaccinated: Find out how to get yourself and your client vaccinated here.

SEIU 775 in the News: Read about what caregivers are doing and how the COVID-19 outbreak is affecting us.

Access to COVID-19 Testing and Health Benefits: Learn more information from SEIU 775 Benefits Group.

HCA Certification Exam Rescheduling: Learn more information from SEIU 775 Benefits Group.

Training Information and Updates for Caregivers: Learn more information from SEIU 775 Benefits Group.

Apply for Unemployment Insurance, Workers’ Comp/L&I, Paid Family Leave Act, or use PTO:

  • Financial Resources for Washington Residents Impacted by COVID-19 – Washington State Department of Financial Institutions
  • If you are interested in getting hours with a new client, you can also sign up with Carina.

Title: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) Resources
Content:
Coronavirus Disease 2019 (COVID-19): Official overview and information from the CDC.

Guidance for Long-Term Care Facilities, Nursing Homes: Additional information for facilities and nursing homes.

Cleaning and Disinfection Recommendations: Environmental cleaning and disinfection recommendations.

Preventing COVID-19 from Spreading: Information on preventing the spread of coronavirus in homes and residential communities.

Frequently Asked Questions

Washington’s “Stay home, Stay Safe” Order:
Question: With the recommendation of the “Stay home, stay safe” policy and social distancing, what should caregivers do? Should we be going to work?

Answer: We have confirmed with the State that home care workers are considered “essential providers” and are allowed to continue to work and provide care for their vulnerable clients. You can find precautions that caregivers should take on below, as well as additional guidance from DSHS about tasks that caregivers can and will be encouraged to do remotely, when possible – such as over the phone – to limit how much you have to leave home and reduce contact while continuing to support your client. If you are at greater risk yourself – such as over the age of 60 with an existing health condition – and you feel it is unsafe for you to go to work, you should call your agency supervisor or case worker and you could potentially qualify for unemployment.

Essential Workforce Permission for Caregiver Letter: We have confirmed with the Governor’s office that it is not necessary for caregivers to carry a letter stating that they are essential workers, but we are happy to provide one, as many of you have been asking for one, and we know many of your employers are providing similar letters. You can get the letter here.

Domestic abuse has been on the rise during the COVID-19 pandemic. Trained experts are available 24/7 to talk confidentially with anyone who is experiencing domestic violence, seeking resources or information, or questioning unhealthy aspects of their relationship. Call the National Domestic Violence Hotline today: 1-800-799-SAFE (7233). Or visit Washington State Coalition against Domestic Violence (WSCADV) to find resources available to caregivers throughout the state of Washington.

Health Insurance:
Question: I lost hours due to the coronavirus and I’m worried that I’m going to lose my health insurance – what can I do?

Answer: We have taken action to ensure home care workers who have Union health insurance won’t lose their coverage if their hours go down as a result of COVID-19. Caregivers will need to notify the Health Benefits Trust that their hours dropped below 80 hours per month as a result of COVID-19, and they will be granted a coverage extension. Keep an eye on your email for details from our Health Benefits Trust on how to report that you’ve lost hours and need this coverage extension.

In response to the outbreak of COVID-19, the Health Care Authority (HCA) is taking steps to ensure that individuals maintain continuity of their Classic Apple Health (Medicaid) coverage. You can find details on the new changes for eligibility here.

Lost Hours:
Question: I lost hours or lost a client due to the coronavirus – what can I do?

Answer: Depending on your situation, you can apply for Unemployment Insurance, Worker’s Comp/L&I, Paid Family Leave Act, or use PTO. You can learn more by clicking below – including taking a quiz that can help point you in the direction of the best resource for you. If you are interested in getting hours with a new client, you can also sign up at CarinaCare.com.

  • If you have lost hours due to COVID-19 and aren’t sure what you can do, please take our quiz to find out which benefits you may be eligible for.
  • Tips for Filing an Unemployment Claim – SEIU 775
  • Workers’ Compensation Coverage and COVID-19 FAQ – Washington State Department of Labor & Industries
  • Unemployment Filing and Appeals Process – Washington State Employment Security Department
  • COVID-19 Scenarios & Benefits Available – Washington State Employment Security Department
  • Information for workers and businesses affected by COVID-19 (coronavirus) – Washington State Employment Security Department
    • Spanish: Trabajadores y empleadores afectados por el COVID-19 (coronavirus)
  • Financial Resources for Washington Residents Impacted by COVID-19 – Washington State Department of Financial Institutions

Client Safety:
Question: What do I do if I or my client gets coronavirus or is exposed to coronavirus?

Answer: This is a big concern of many caregivers. We encourage you to call your/your client’s primary care physician, and contact your client’s case manager if you are an IP or your supervisor if you are an agency provider. The CDC has a resource guide for living with someone or sharing close quarters with someone with coronavirus. Additionally, the Washington State Department of Health has established a call center to address questions from the public – their number is 1-800-525-0127.

Home Care Guidance for Tele-Health from DSHS: View this document for a list of tasks that can now be done by phone or remotely, and which tasks can only be provided in person. If you work for a private home care agency consult with your agency supervisor before doing tasks by phone or remotely.

  • 远程健康家庭护理指导 (中文 – Chinese) | 원격 의료를 위한 가정 간호 지침 (한국어 – Korean) |Руководство по уходу на дому в режиме телемедицины (российский – Russian) |  Guía de atención domiciliaria sobre telemedicina (Español – Spanish) | Hướng Dẫn Chăm Sóc Tại Nhà đối với Dịch Vụ Chăm Sóc Sức Khỏe Từ Xa (Tiểng Việt –  Vietnamese)

COVID-19 Home Health. Home Care Guidelines: This document provides guidance for staff of home care, home health and hospice agencies to use when helping patients around the house or with personal or clinical care.

  • The document is now available in Amharic, Arabic, Cambodian, Chinese, English, Spanish, Korean, Laotian, Russian, Samoan, Somali, Tagalog, Ukrainian and Vietnamese. All versions of the document are available on ALTSA’s COVID-19 Provider Information page.

PPE:
Question: How can caregivers get access to PPE?

Answer: July 1 Update: If you’re an Individual Provider, you can now request enough PPE – including surgical masks, gloves, gowns, and face shields – for a 31-day period by contacting your local Area Agency on Aging (AAA) or the Developmental Disabilities Administration (DDA). Learn more here. 

April 24 Update: In response to our demands, the State will now have cloth masks to distribute out to every single Individual Provider via mail in May that they have addresses for. If you have a client with a confirmed or suspected case of COVID-19, you’ll be able to access an N95 mask and other essential PPE. In the meantime, our SEIU 775 Benefits Group has instructions for how you can make masks at home.

There is a national shortage of PPE (personal protective equipment like masks) and the Federal Government has fallen down on getting more produced and out to caregivers who need it. We are also working with local public health agencies to develop guidance for caregivers on safe and affordable alternatives that can help protect caregivers while we push for more official PPE to be produced.Unless you or your client has a confirmed coronavirus diagnosis, the CDC recommends following everyday preventive actions, such as washing your hands, covering your cough, and staying home when you are sick.

If you are caring for someone who is sick with COVID-19, please read the COVID-19 Guidance for In-Home Caregivers with Limited Personal Protective Equipment (PPE).

Free gloves for caregivers are available to some IPs through their clients’ health benefit. Please visit the SEIU 775 Benefits Group webpage for instructions.

After advocating hard with the Governor’s office and DSHS, we successfully pushed to have home care workers included in the official state “priority lists” for access to PPE.

DSHS has new guidelines for in-home caregivers and PPE: Caregivers who provide care for someone who is “Confirmed” (tested positive for COVID-19) or “Suspected” (pending test results OR medical provider verified the symptoms are consistent with COVID-19, but will not test) can request PPE through your Area Agency on Aging (AAA).

This is a step forward – and some caregivers will be able to get PPE – but it’s not enough.

Working People:
Question: With so many people losing hours and jobs, is there anything we can do to help?

Answer: We know that many people that work at closed businesses are out of work. We are joining with SEIU nationally and other unions to demand economic stimulus focused on working people, not big corporations. Among other things, we are calling for meaningful income replacement checks for all, regardless of citizenship or employment status. You can find out more at protectallworkers.org.

Childcare:
Question: I need to take care of my client, but schools are closed so I have kids at home. What can we do about childcare?

Answer: The State of Washington has been working on a plan to provide free emergency childcare to healthcare workers on the frontlines of the crisis. We have been in touch with the Governor’s office and the Superintendent of Public Instruction to make very clear that home care and nursing home workers must be included in any plans for emergency childcare, and the good news is they agree with us! The bad news is the plans are rolling out too slowly in some school districts for those of you trying to care for your kids and your clients. We are pushing to make sure caregivers have access to childcare if they need it, and will be sending out information as we get it. In the meantime, please tell us if you need childcare and aren’t able to access it.

King County Emergency Child Care: Essential workers who live or work in King County AND need childcare can help you access free emergency child care. Learn more here.

Title: Electronic Visitation Verification FAQ
Content:
January 15, 2021

IPOne의 새로운 EVV (Electronic Visitation Verification) 시스템이 대부분의 간병인에게 적절하게 작동해서 여러분 모두가 급여를 전액 지불 받기를 원합니다.

그러나, 1/15 급여에서 근무 시간에 대한 급여 또는 12/16-12/31 급여 기간에 입력된 근무 시간 혹은 마일리지가이누락된 경우에는 다음 단계를 진행해서 저희가 DSHS에 이의를 제기할 수 있도록 해주십시오. 지난 수 년간 간병인은 이의 제기를 통해 IPOne 시스템 장애로 인한 지불 지연 및/또는 급여 누락으로 인한 손해에 대한 벌금,이자 및 배상금으로 수십만 달러를 보상 받았습니다.

다음은 여러분의 체불 임금 및 손해 배상을 받을 수 있도록 이의를 적절하게 제기하기 위해 필요한 정보를 저희가 확보할 수 있는 방법입니다.

  • Member Resource Center 전화 1 (866) 371-3200으로 연락해서 문제를 알려주십시오.
  • IPOne에 통화한 내역을 기록해 두십시오. 몇 번이나 전화하셨습니까? 얼마나 오래 기다리셨습니까? 콜백을 받기까지 얼마나 걸렸습니까?
  • 초과 인출 수수료, 청구서 또는 임대료의 연체료 등과 같이 지연되거나 불완전한 임금 지불로 인해 발생한 모든 손해를 기록해 두십시오.

저희는 여러분이 일한 시간에 대해 정당한 급여를 받을 수 있도록 열심히 노력하고 있습니다. 우리는 함께 협력해서 새로운 EVV 시스템에서 발생하는 문제에 대해 주정부와 IPOne에 책임을 물을 수 있습니다. 

연방 명령에 따라 12월 16일부터 간병인은 EVV(Electronic Visitation Verification)를 통해 근무 시간을 기록해야 합니다.   

왜 이렇게 해야 합니까?  

  • 의회에서 통과된 21st Century Cures Act는 주정부가 비용을 분담하는 공공 서비스의 경우EVV(Electronic Visitation Verification) 시스템을 사용하도록 요구하는 새로운 규정을 명시하고 있습니다. 이 규정은 모든 가정 및 지역사회 기반 간병 서비스에 적용됩니다. 입주 제공자가 아닌 모든 간병인은 클라이언트에게 서비스를 제공하기 위해 새로운 규칙을 따라야 합니다.  
  • 주정부가 연방에서 요구하는 EVV를 시행하지 않는 경우, 연방 Medicaid 자금지원이 끊길 수도 있습니다. 

이러한 시스템 전환 기간에 Union은 우리의 권리를 어떻게 보호했습니까?   

  • 입주 간병인에 대한 면제. 현재와 동일한 방식으로 근무 시간을 제출할 수 있도록 12월 16일 이전에 IPOne에서 귀하의 설정을 업데이트해야 합니다.   
  • 개인 정보 및 데이터를 보호하기 위한 개인 정보 보호 조치.   
  • 스마트 폰이 없는 간병인이 다른 방법으로 근무 시간을 보고할 수 있도록 하는 방안들을 관철시켰습니다. 스마트 폰이 없는 경우 필요에 따라 클라이언트의 집에서 전화를 통해 근무 시간을 기록할 수 있습니다.   
  • EVV 시스템이 작동하지 않거나 고장난 경우 근무 시간표를 제출하는 다른 방법들을 보장 받았습니다.    

간병인인 제가 따라야 하는 절차는 무엇입니까?  

  • 입주 제공자는 EVV에서 면제되지만 IPOne 포털에서 입주 제공자 면제 자격을 신청해야 합니다. 
  • 입주 제공자를 제외한 모든  간병인은 스마트 폰 또는 태블릿의 Time4Care 앱을 통하거나 클라이언트의등록된 전화를 사용하여 근무 시간을 기록해야 합니다.  
  • Time4Care 모바일 앱(iPhone의 경우 App Store, 또는 Android의 경우 Google Play에서)을 스마트 폰 또는 태블릿에 다운로드해야 합니다. 이렇게 하면 근무시간 보고를 가장 간편하게 관리할 수 있습니다.   
  • 자신의 IPOne 사용자 이름 및 비밀번호를 사용해서 Time4Care에 로그인하게 됩니다. 
  • 태블릿이나 스마트 폰이 없는 경우 IPOne에서 제공하는 근무 시간 보고 핫라인으로 전화해서 근무 시간을 보고할 수도 있습니다. 가능하면 앱을 사용하도록 권장합니다.  

EVV 방식을 준비하려면 다음 체크리스트를 따르십시오. 

  • IPOne에서 정보 업데이트  
  • 올바른 자료를 얻을 수 있도록 선호하는 언어를 설정하십시오. 
  • 향후 (앱이 아닌) 전화로 EVV 보고를 하게 될 경우를 대비해 클라이언트의 전화번호를 입력하십시오. 
  • 간병인 본인의 휴대폰과 이메일을 최신 정보로 업데이트하십시오. 
  • 입주 제공자: IPOne 포털에서 Live-In Exemption(입주 제공자 면제, LIE)를 선택하십시오(자세한 내용은 아래 참조). 
  • Time4Care 교육에 참석 
  • Time4Care 앱 다운로드 
  • 휴대폰 또는 태블릿에서 GPS 활성화 

{아래 순서도} 

추가 자료: 

  • Time4Care에 대한 온라인 교육에 가입하십시오. 
  • Time4Care 사용 방법에 대한 비디오 시청

Title: 电子访问验证，EVV FAQ
Content:
January 15, 2021

我们希望 IPOne 的新 Electronic Visitation Verification（电子访问验证，EVV）系统对于大多数护理人员来说都运行正常，让您今天能够收到全额工资。

但是，如果您 1 月 15 日的工资单遗漏了任何从12 月 16 日至 12 月 31 日的工时的报酬或任何里程，请在今天采取以下步骤以支持您向 DSHS 提起成功的申诉。在过去几年的申诉中，针对因 IPOne 系统故障导致的迟付和/或漏付而造成的损失，我们为护理人员赢取了数十万美元的赔款、利息和报销。

请遵循下列说明，确保我们得到提起成功申诉所需的信息，以赢得您的欠付工资和损失补偿：

  • 拨打 1 (866) 371-3200 致电 Member Resource Center（成员资源中心）报告您遇到的问题。
  • 记录您的 IPOne 呼叫尝试。您拨打了几次电话？您等待接听的时间有多长？您是否有收到回电？
  • 请记录因迟付或漏付造成的任何损失，如透支费、账单或房租的滞纳金等。

我们将努力确保您能得到您应得的所有报酬。只要我们共同努力，就能让州政府和 IPOne 对新 EVV 系统带来的各种困扰负起应有的责任。 

根据联邦政府规定，从 12 月 16 日开始，护理人员将需要通过 Electronic Visitation Verification（电子访问验证，EVV）来记录工时。  

为什么会发生这一变化？ 

  • 国会通过的 21st Century Cures Act（《21 世纪治愈法案》）制定了新的规定，要求各州使用 Electronic Visitation Verification（电子访问验证，EVV）系统，以确保由州政府支付的服务提供给需要这些服务的客户。这个变化适用于所有居家护理服务和社区护理服务。所有非住家 IP 必须遵守新的规定，以便为客户提供服务。 
  • 如果州政府不执行联邦政府要求的 EVV，我们可能失去联邦政府的 Medicaid 资助。

在这次过渡中，我们的工会采取了哪些行动来保护我们的权利？  

  • 针对住家护理人员的豁免。您需要在 12 月 16 日之前在 IPOne 网站中更新自己的设置，以确保您可以采用与目前相同的方式来记录工时。  
  • 保护您的个人信息和数据的隐私措施。  
  • 我们为没有智能手机的服务提供者争取并赢得了灵活报告的方式。如果您没有智能手机，也可以使用客户家中的电话来记录工时.  
  • 如果 EVV 系统无法工作或发生崩溃，我们也确保您有办法提交考勤单。   

我必须做些什么？ 

  • 住家服务提供者不需要使用 EVV，但需要在 IPOne Portal（IPOne 网站）中选择针对住家护理人员的豁免。
  • 所有非住家 IP 需要通过智能手机或平板电脑在 Time4Care 应用程序中记录工时，或使用客户家中注册过的电话进行记录。 
  • 您将需要在自己的手机或平板电脑上下载 Time4Care 移动应用程序（下载地址为：App Store (iPhone) 或 Google Play (Android)。这将是您管理工时报告的最简单方式。  
  • 您将使用自己的 IPOne 用户名和密码来登录 Time4Care。
  • 如果您没有智能手机或平板电脑，也可以通过拨打 IPOne 提供的工时报告热线来报告工时。如非必要，我们建议您使用应用程序报告工时。 

按照此检查表来为 EVV 的实施做好准备：

  • 在 IPOne 中更新信息
    • 设置您的首选语言，以便获得正确的资料
    • 输入客户的号码，以备将来需要通过使用 EVV
    • 更新您的电话号码和电子邮箱地址
    • 住家服务提供者：在 IPOne Portal（IPOne 门户网站）中选择针对住家护理人员的豁免 (LIE)（见下方详情）
    • 参加 Time4Care 培训
    • 下载 Time4Care 应用程序
    • 在手机或平板电脑上启用 GPS

{见下方流程图}

其他资源：

  • 注册参加 Time4Care 在线培训
    • 观看关于如何使用 Time4Care 的视频

Title: Câu Hỏi Thường Gặp Về EVV
Content:
January 15, 2021

Chúng tôi hy vọng rằng hệ thống Xác Minh Truy Cập Điện Tử (EVV) mới của IPOne hoạt động tốt đối với hầu hết chăm sóc viên và bạn hiện được trả lương đầy đủ.

Tuy nhiên, nếu tiền lương chi trả cho bạn vào ngày 15 tháng 1 thiếu BẤT KỲ khoản chi trả nào cho số giờ đã làm hoặc số dặm đã nhập trong kỳ lương 16/12-31/12, hãy thực hiện các bước sau đây ngay hôm nay để hỗ trợ chúng tôi khiếu nại DSHS thành công. Thông qua khiếu nại trong nhiều năm qua, chúng tôi đã giúp các chăm sóc viên giành lại được hàng trăm nghìn đô la tiền phí phạt, tiền lãi suất và tiền hoàn trả cho những thiệt hại vì trả lương thiếu và/hoặc muộn do lỗi hệ thống của IPOne

Sau đây là cách bạn có thể giúp đảm bảo chúng tôi có được những thông tin cần thiết để gửi khiếu nại thành công, nhờ đó giành lại được tiền lương và tiền bồi thường thiệt hại:

  • Gọi điện cho Trung Tâm Nguồn Lực Thành Viên theo số 1 (866) 371-3200 để báo sự cố.
  • Theo dõi những lần bạn gọi điện đến IPOne. Bạn đã gọi điện bao nhiêu lần? Bạn phải chờ máy trong bao lâu? Sau bao lâu thì bạn nhận được cuộc gọi lại?
  • Lưu giữ hồ sơ về bất kỳ và tất cả thiệt hại do trả lương muộn hoặc không đầy đủ, chẳng hạn như phí bội chi, phí thanh toán muộn tiền hóa đơn hoặc tiền thuê nhà, v.v..

Chúng tôi đang hết sức nỗ lực nhằm đảm bảo bạn được trả lương cho số giờ bạn đã làm. Khi đoàn kết lại, chúng ta có thể khiến tiểu bang và IPOne chịu trách nhiệm về những thách thức mà hệ thống EVV mới gây ra. 

Kể từ ngày 16 tháng 12, theo chỉ thị của Liên Bang, các chăm sóc viên sẽ phải ghi lại số giờ làm việc qua hệ thống Xác Minh Truy Cập Điện Tử (EVV).  

Tại sao điều này diễn ra? 

  • Đạo Luật Chữa Bệnh Thế Kỷ 21 do Quốc Hội thông qua đề ra những quy tắc mới yêu cầu các tiểu bang phải sử dụng hệ thống Xác Minh Truy Cập Điện Tử (EVV) nhằm đảm bảo các dịch vụ mà tiểu bang đài thọ được cung cấp cho những thân chủ cần đến các dịch vụ đó. Đạo luật này áp dụng cho tất cả dịch vụ chăm sóc tại Nhà và Cộng Đồng. Mọi nhà cung cấp cá nhân không phải là nhà cung cấp tại chỗ đều phải tuân thủ các quy tắc mới này khi cung cấp dịch vụ cho thân chủ của họ. 
  • Nếu tiểu bang không triển khai hệ thống Xác Minh Truy Cập Điện Tử (EVV) theo yêu cầu của liên bang thì chúng ta có thể bị mất nguồn quỹ tài trợ Medicaid của liên bang.

Liên Đoàn đã làm gì để bảo vệ quyền lợi của chúng ta trong quá trình chuyển đổi này?  

  • Miễn trừ cho các chăm sóc viên tại chỗ. Bạn cần cập nhật các tùy chọn cài đặt của mình trong IPOne trước ngày 16 tháng 12 để đảm bảo rằng bạn có thể tiếp tục gửi số giờ làm việc theo như cách bạn đang làm bây giờ.  
  • Áp dụng các biện pháp bảo mật để bảo vệ dữ liệu và thông tin cá nhân của bạn.  
  • Chúng ta đã đấu tranh để những nhà cung cấp không sử dụng điện thoại thông minh có thể báo cáo một cách linh hoạt và chúng ta đã thành công. Nếu không có điện thoại thông minh, bạn có thể sử dụng điện thoại cố định tại nhà của thân chủ để ghi lại số giờ làm việc nếu cần.  
  • Chuẩn bị sẵn các phương thức được bảo đảm để hỗ trợ bạn gửi bảng chấm công nếu hệ thống EVV không hoạt động hoặc bị hỏng.   

Tôi phải làm gì? 

  • Nhà Cung Cấp Tại Chỗ được miễn EVV nhưng cần đăng ký miễn trừ cho nhà cung cấp tại chỗ trên Cổng Thông Tin IPOne.
  • Mọi nhà cung cấp cá nhân không sống cùng với thân chủ sẽ phải ghi lại số giờ làm việc qua ứng dụng Time4Care trên điện thoại thông minh hoặc máy tính bảng hoặc sử dụng điện thoại cố định đã đăng ký của thân chủ. 
  • Bạn cần tải ứng dụng Time4Care dành cho thiết bị di động (từ App Store nếu bạn dùng iPhone hoặc Google Play nếu bạn dùng thiết bị Android) xuống điện thoại hoặc máy tính bảng của bạn. Đây là cách dễ nhất để bạn quản lý số giờ báo cáo.  
  • Bạn sẽ sử dụng tên người dùng và mật khẩu IPOne của mình để đăng nhập vào Time4Care.
  • Nếu không có máy tính bảng hoặc điện thoại thông minh, bạn cũng có thể báo cáo số giờ làm việc bằng cách gọi điện đến đường dây nóng báo cáo Số Giờ Làm Việc do IPOne cung cấp. Bạn nên dùng ứng dụng này nếu có thể. 

Hãy làm theo danh sách kiểm tra này để chuẩn bị tiến hành Xác Minh Truy Cập Điện Tử (EVV):

  • Cập nhật thông tin trong IPOne
    • Đặt ngôn ngữ ưu tiên để bạn nhận được đúng tài liệu
    • Nhập số điện thoại cố định của thân chủ phòng trường hợp bạn cần phải sử dụng điện thoại cố định để Xác Minh Truy Cập Điện Tử (EVV) trong tương lai
    • Cập nhật số điện thoại và email của bạn để luôn nhận được thông tin cập nhật
    • Nhà Cung Cấp Tại Chỗ: Hãy đăng ký Miễn Trừ Cho Nhà Cung Cấp Tại Chỗ (LIE) trên cổng thông tin IPOne (Thông tin chi tiết ở bên dưới)
    • Tham Dự một Chương Trình Đào Tạo về Time4Care
    • Tải Ứng Dụng Time4Care Xuống
    • Bật GPS trên điện thoại hoặc máy tính bảng

Các nguồn trợ giúp khác:

  • Đăng ký tham gia một chương trình đào tạo trực tuyến trên Time4Care
  • Xem video về cách sử dụng Time4Care

Title: COVID-19 WA Vaccines
Content:
UPDATE: The COVID vaccine is now required for Nursing Home workers. Read more here.

HOW TO GET THE COVID-19 VACCINE AND BOOSTER

Caregivers around the State are continuing to receive the safe and effective COVID-19 vaccines.  Everyone in the State 5 years of age and older is able to get their COVID vaccine shot and caregivers are eligible to receive booster shots.

COVID Vaccine Booster Shots

All caregivers are eligible for their first COIVD booster shot because we are healthcare professionals.

  • If you got the Pfizer or Moderna shot, you can get a booster if it’s been at least 5 months since your second shot. You can get any of the authorized COVID vaccines as your booster.
  • If you got the Johnson & Johnson/Janssen shot, you can get a booster if it’s been at last 2 months after your shot. You can get any of the authorized COVID vaccines as your booster.

Find a vaccine provider:   

  • By phone or text. Call the DOH Statewide Vaccine Finder phone line at 1-800-525-0127 or 833-VAX-HELP, then press # and 1 for English, 2 for Spanish, and 3 for all other languages. Text your zip code to GETVAX (438829) or VACUNA (822862) to find a vaccine provider near you.
  • Online. You can also look online for an appointment at the DOH vaccine locator.
  • Through Kaiser Permanente. Kaiser Permanente is vaccinating everyone, even if you don’t have Kaiser health insurance. Go here to make a COVID-19 vaccination appointment at Kaiser Permanente or by calling 1-800-352-3610.
  • At Home. If you or your client are not able to leave home for a vaccine, you can request Homebound Vaccination Services. To do so:
    • Call the COVID-19 Assistance Hotline at 1-800-525-0127, then press #. Let them know you need “homebound vaccination services”.
    • Complete this form to request Homebound Vaccination Services.
    • Call your local health department (contact information can be found here) and tell them you need “homebound vaccination services”.

Credentials are not needed to receive the COVID-19 vaccine.

“I was excited to get vaccinated to protect my loved ones and residents, along with myself — because it’s been proven safe and effective.”

— Shelly Hughes, CNA North Cascades Health & Rehabilitation, Bellingham

Frequently Asked Questions about COVID-19 Vaccines

Q: Do I need insurance to get the vaccine?

A: No, the COVID-19 vaccine is free for everyone and no insurance is needed. Vaccination providers cannot charge you for the vaccine, including copays or coinsurance, or deny the vaccine to anyone without health insurance, or who is underinsured or out of network.

Q: Who can get the vaccine now in Washington state?

A: Anyone 5 years of age or older is now eligible to get the COVID-19 vaccine.

Q: My client can’t leave home. How do I get the vaccine for them?

A: You can request “homebound vaccination services”. To do so:

  • Call the COVID-19 Assistance Hotline at 1-800-525-0127, then press #. Let them know you need “homebound vaccination services”.
  • Complete this form to request homebound vaccination services.
  • Call your local health department (contact information can be found here) and tell them you need “homebound vaccination services”.

Q: Do I still need the vaccine if I already had COVID?

A: Yes, you should be vaccinated regardless of whether you already had COVID-19. That’s because experts do not yet know how long you are protected from getting sick again after recovering from COVID-19. Even if you have already recovered from COVID-19, it is possible that you could be infected with the virus that causes COVID-19 again.

Q: I’m a caregiver, where can I get PPE?

A: Together we fought for and won free PPE for caregivers. APs should request PPE through their agencies. IPs can order one PPE kit per month, per client, through Workday in CDWA’s DirectMyCare portal. Instructions on ordering are here.  

Q: Can I get COVID-19 from the Vaccine?

A: No. There are no live virus particles. While you might feel minor, temporary side effects from the injection, it is impossible to contract the virus from the vaccine.

Q: Will the vaccine cause side effects? If so, how long might they last?

A: Some people who get a COVID-19 vaccine will experience side effects, particularly after a second dose. The side effects of the vaccine appear to be minor and temporary. Participants have reported pain at the injection site, fatigue, and occasional fever, headache, or aching muscles and joints. These side effects fade within 1-2 days.

These side effects are actually common with all vaccines: they are a sign that a vaccine is working and triggering an immune response.

Title: Página de ejemplo
Content:
Esta es una página de ejemplo. Se diferencia de una publicación en un blog en que permanece en un solo lugar y no es visible al navegar en el sitio (en la mayoría de temas). La mayoría de las personas comienzan con una página de “Acerca de nosotros” que sirve para que se presenten ante los posibles visitantes del sitio. Dice algo como esto:

¡Hola! Por el día, trabajo como mensajero en bicicleta, y por la noche, soy aspirante a actor. Este es mi sitio web. Vivo en Los Ángeles, tengo un perro genial llamado Jack, y me gusta la piña colada. (Y ser sorprendido por la lluvia.)

...o algo como esto:

La empresa de cacharros XYZ fue fundada en 1971 y desde entonces, ofrece cacharros de calidad al público en general. XYZ, ubicada en Ciudad Gótica, tiene más de 2,000 empleados y hace una gran cantidad de cosas asombrosas por la comunidad de la ciudad.

Como nuevo usuario de WordPress, deberá ir a su panel de control para borrar esta página y crear páginas nuevas para su contenido. ¡Diviértase!

Title: Adam Glickman
Content:
Adam Glickman

Secretary-Treasurer de SEIU 775

Adam ha sido defensor toda su vida de los derechos de los trabajadores y fue uno de los primeros empleados de SEIU 775. Se mudó al estado de Washington a finales del año 2000 y ayudó a impulsar la novedosa medida en las votaciones que les otorgó a los trabajadores de atención domiciliaria de individual providers (proveedores individuales) pagados por el estado el derecho a conformar nuestra Unión. Después de trabajar en varios roles en la Unión, fue elegido como el primer Vice President y ahora como Secretary-Treasurer. Dentro de sus funciones está la supervisión del trabajo de Public Affairs (Departamento de Asuntos Públicos) de la Unión (incluidas las relaciones y los compromisos políticos con el Gobierno y la comunidad), así como el programa Legal, el presupuesto y las finanzas de la Unión. Como principal negociador del contrato de atención domiciliaria para proveedores individuales de Washington, uno de los contratos para cuidadores más completos y equitativos en la nación, sus esfuerzos han ayudado a que los cuidadores del estado de Washington sean los primeros de la nación que ganan un salario mínimo de $15 la hora (con aspiración de que se conviertan en más de $17) y tienen beneficio de jubilación.

Además de su trabajo en SEIU 775, Adam ha desempeñado un rol clave en la formación y crecimiento de una variedad de organizaciones progresistas en todo Washington. Fue miembro fundador de la junta directiva de Fuse Washington y Win-Win Network (afiliado de America Votes), y es miembro de la junta directiva de One America Votes, la organización política por los derechos de los inmigrantes más grande del estado.

Por último, Adam es Chair de la junta directiva de SEIU 775 Training Partnership , una de las instituciones educativas más grandes de Washington, y trabaja en las juntas directivas de Health Benefits Trust de SEIU 775, SEIU 775 Secure Retirement Plan (plan de jubilación asegurada de SEIU 775) y Carina, el servicio en línea para la búsqueda de empleo en atención domiciliaria.

Title: Para miembros nuevos
Content:
¡Bienvenido a SEIU 775! 

Nuestra Unión representa a 45,000 cuidadores de atención domiciliaria, nursing homes (asilos para ancianos) y centros residenciales que se dedican a mejorar las vidas de todos los trabajadores de atención a largo plazo y las personas bajo su cuidado. Nos emociona darle la bienvenida a la familia de nuestra Unión, donde con solo una llamada telefónica podemos ayudarle a cuidar de su cliente y de usted mismo.

La voz de los cuidadores es más fuerte cuando estamos unidos y nos apoyamos. Únase a los miles de compañeros cuidadores que quieren defenderse a sí mismos, a otros cuidadores y a las personas bajo su cuidado.

Antes de que nuestra Unión fuera fundada en el 2002, los cuidadores ganaban el salario mínimo y no eran respetados. Desde entonces, hemos conseguido:

  • Mejores salarios.
  • Mejores beneficios.
  • Mejor entrenamiento.

La membresía de SEIU 775 es valiosa. Únicamente los miembros son elegibles para recibir los descuentos y beneficios especiales de Membership Plus. Además, únicamente los miembros tienen derecho a participar sin restricciones en los asuntos internos de la Unión, votar por los funcionarios de la Unión, postularse a cargos dentro de la Unión, formar parte de las negociaciones colectivas y votar para rechazar o ratificar el acuerdo de negociación colectiva de su unidad de negociación.

Puede comunicarse con nosotros en cualquier momento contactando al Member Resource Center (Centro de Información para Miembros) a la línea 1-866-371-3200 o escribiendo a mrc@seiu775.org.

Bienvenido a SEIU 775. Juntos somos más fuertes, por nosotros, nuestras familias, nuestras comunidades y nuestros clientes.

Title: Contratos de nursing homes (asilos para ancianos)
Empleo
Content:
Trabaje en SEIU 775

La misión de SEIU 775 es unir las fuerzas de todas las personas trabajadoras y sus familias con el fin de mejorar nuestras vidas y marcar el camino hacia un mundo más justo y humanitario. Representamos a más de 45,000 trabajadores de atención a largo plazo que brindan atención domiciliaria de calidad, atención en nursing homes (asilos para ancianos) y prestan servicios de Adult Day Health (atención de día para adultos) en el estado de Washington y Montana. Somos líderes dentro de la comunidad progresista, y tomamos decisiones audaces y usamos enfoques dinámicos para abordar la política y la creación de uniones.

Vacantes disponibles en SEIU 775

Title: No nos ignorarán más
Content:
Una historia de luchas y victorias

Hace quince años, los cuidadores se unieron y formaron SEIU 775. En ese entonces, ganábamos $7.18 la hora, sin beneficios: sin atención médica, sin jubilación, sin licencia por enfermedad ni Paid Time Off (tiempo de vacaciones pagadas, PTO), sin compensación para trabajadores (L&I), sin entrenamiento profesional y sin respeto. Desde ese momento en que nos unimos y comenzamos a hacernos escuchar, hemos duplicado ese salario (y los cuidadores con más experiencia ganan aún más). Pero, al mismo tiempo, jamás nos habíamos enfrentado a una organización extremista tan grande y organizada como la Freedom Foundation. Esta organización trata de deshacer lo que hemos conseguido desde el 2001, silenciar nuestras voces y destruir todo aquello por lo que hemos luchado y trabajado. Pero somos más fuertes que los extremistas. Sabemos la verdad: los cuidadores luchamos por nosotros mismos y por aquellos bajo nuestro cuidado. Eso quiere decir que no daremos marcha atrás. ¡Si permanecemos unidos, venceremos!

Title: Conviértase en miembro
Content:
No solo se trata de un trabajo mejor; se trata de un mundo mejor.

Siga estos sencillos pasos para demostrar su compromiso con SEIU 775 y las personas bajo su cuidado.  Formar parte de SEIU 775 significa luchar por una vida mejor para usted y aquellas personas bajo su cuidado. Como miembro de SEIU 775, usted forma parte de un legado de cuidadores que luchan por lo correcto. En el principio, éramos una fuerza laboral que ganaba un salario mínimo, no teníamos beneficios y no nos respetaban. Ahora, somos una fuerza respetada que lucha por mejorar las vidas de las personas trabajadoras y sus familias, y por sacar a los cuidadores de la pobreza. Aún nos queda mucho por hacer. Cuando usted se compromete con SEIU 775, pasa a formar parte de un grupo de miles de personas comprometidas a seguir mejorando los servicios vitales que prestamos. Conviértase en miembro hoy.

Title: Organizaciones aliadas
Content:
Working Washington

Working Washington es una coalición de personas naturales, asociaciones de vecinos, grupos de inmigrantes, organizaciones de derechos civiles, personas de fe y trabajadores unidos con el objetivo de mejorar las condiciones de trabajo y conseguir una economía más justa.

Fuse

Fuse reúne a los residentes de Washington que apoyan a los líderes y las causas progresistas.  Ayudamos a que las personas que quieren resolver los problemas del estado con soluciones de sentido común trabajen juntas para conseguir sus metas.

Caring Across Generations

Caring Across Generations es una campaña que promueve el cuidado y el apoyo de calidad, y una vida digna para todas las generaciones de estadounidenses.

Title: ¿Quién debería ser elegido como el próximo Governor de Washington?
Content:
Nuestra decisión, nuestros valores

Los miembros de SEIU se enorgullecen de apoyar a Jay Inslee como el candidato más adecuado al puesto de Governor, de acuerdo con su trayectoria laboral, experiencia como líder e historial de votación. Para saber a qué otros candidatos respaldamos en el estado, visite https://seiu775.ivykitten.com/endorsements
author: SEIU Healthcare 775NW

Title: Investigación
Content:
Descargue copias de nuestros trabajos de investigación sobre temas importantes y aspectos de la comunidad de atención domiciliaria

La atención domiciliaria y las comunidades de color: este estudio de antecedentes de dos páginas demuestra la importancia de promover la igualdad racial y proteger el programa de atención domiciliaria de Washington. Lo que el censo nos dice acerca de la atención domiciliaria: este panorama de una página contiene información demográfica sobre la edad, género, raza, nacionalidad, estado de aseguramiento médico y empleo de los trabajadores de atención domiciliaria en el estado de Washington.
author: SEIU Healthcare 775NW

Title: Un día en los zapatos de un cuidador
Content: Haga clic en el siguiente botón para ver un video de Jay Inslee trabajando como asistente de atención domiciliaria por un día.

Title: Jay Inslee nos apoya
Content:
Jay Inslee no solo nos apoya. Él nos comprende. Él defiende nuestra lucha. Jay Inslee nos apoya. Jay Inslee es nuestra elección como candidato a Governor del estado de Washington. Jay Inslee se puso en los zapatos de un cuidador por un día para entender mejor la energía, dedicación y servicio profesional que los cuidadores les brindan a sus clientes y residentes. Él fue testigo de nuestro arduo trabajo y de lo mucho que nuestros clientes dependen de nuestros servicios. Jay Inslee es el mejor candidato porque siempre ha apoyado los servicios de atención a largo plazo de calidad. Jay ha defendido a las personas de edad avanzada y las personas con discapacidad. Jay está a favor de que todas las familias trabajadoras de Washington tengan un salario digno. Jay apoya la idea de que todos tengamos beneficios de atención médica. Además, Jay quiere que nuestros programas de entrenamiento cuenten con mayor financiación.

Y usted, ¿también nos apoya?

Regístrese para saber cómo puede ayudarnos a difundir nuestro apoyo a Jay Inslee. ¡Vamos a crear un movimiento de cuidadores que elija a un gobernador que nos ayude a marcar la diferencia!
* significa que el campo es obligatorio

Title: David Rolf
Content: David Rolf es conocido a nivel internacional como un novedoso líder laboral y analista del futuro del trabajo y el empleo. Fue uno de los líderes que forjaron las históricas luchas en las que ganamos un salario digno de $15 en SeaTac y Seattle, Washington. Se desempeña como International Vice President de la Service Employees International Union (SEIU) y como President Emeritus de SEIU 775, la cual representa a más de 45,000 trabajadores de atención a largo plazo en el noroeste del Pacífico. The American Prospect lo llamó “el organizador de uniones más exitoso de los últimos 15 años”, y agregó que “ningún otro estadounidense partidario de la unión ha reunido a tantos trabajadores ni les ha ayudado a obtener victorias tan importantes como él”. David escribe y habla frecuentemente de las alternativas que los movimientos de trabajadores tendrán en el futuro, y es el autor del libro Fight for Fifteen: The Right Wage for a Working America (New Press, 2016). Su trabajo ha sido publicado en The American Prospect, The Nation, Aspen Journal of Ideas, Social Policy y Spotlight on Poverty. David está creando un nuevo movimiento de trabajadores, fundando organizaciones como Fair Work Center, Working Washington y The Workers Lab. Fair Work Center es una plataforma con sede en Seattle que ayuda a los trabajadores a comprender y ejercer sus derechos legales, y además ayuda a hacer cumplir las leyes relacionadas con el trabajo. Working Washington es una organización estatal que lucha por la justicia económica y los derechos de los trabajadores dentro del estado de Washington. Workers Lab, con sede en California, invierte en proyectos para crear el movimiento de los trabajadores de la nueva generación y generar poder económico a gran escala para las personas trabajadoras, a la vez que construye modelos autosuficientes de utilidades organizacionales. También es el fundador y Chair de la junta directiva de SEIU 775 Benefits Group, que les brinda beneficios de entrenamiento, atención médica y jubilación a los trabajadores de atención domiciliaria del estado de Washington. Benefits Group es la organización de desarrollo de la fuerza laboral de atención domiciliaria más grande del país, y es la única organización que ofrece entrenamiento de aprendizaje registrado avanzado para los trabajadores de atención domiciliaria. Además de brindar oportunidades laborales para los cuidadores, Benefits Group ofrece beneficios de salud completos y asequibles, así como el primer fondo de pensiones de la nación dirigido a los trabajadores de atención domiciliaria. David nació y creció en Cincinnati, Ohio, y después de graduarse del Bard College se unió a SEIU como organizador en 1991. Él y su esposa viven en Seattle.

Title: Mi Unión
Content:
SEIU Healthcare 775 se ha propuesto la audaz meta de sacar a todos los cuidadores de la pobreza. ¿Qué quiere decir “sacarlos de la pobreza”?
  1. Un salario digno. Un salario de $17.50/hora se considera como digno, ya que, con suficientes horas de trabajo, la mayoría de cuidadores podrían vivir y mantener a sus familias de forma digna.
  2. Trabajo a tiempo completo. Los recortes de horas han diezmado los ingresos de los cuidadores y han afectado la calidad del cuidado de sus clientes. Todos los trabajadores deberían estar en capacidad de trabajar horas a tiempo completo, si así lo desean, y los clientes deberían recibir atención durante la cantidad de horas necesarias a fin de garantizar un cuidado de calidad.
  3. Atención médica asequible. Todos los trabajadores de atención a largo plazo necesitan acceso a atención médica asequible para ellos y sus familias, la cual debería incluir también a los trabajadores a tiempo parcial, y permitir que los trabajadores con varios empleos a tiempo parcial sean elegibles para cobertura
  4. Jubilación asegurada. Los trabajadores de atención a largo plazo tienen derecho a jubilarse alrededor de los 65 años y no vivir en la pobreza. Esto quiere decir que necesitamos un beneficio o sistema de jubilación que funcione para los cuidadores “de por vida” y para aquellos que solo se desempeñan durante una parte de su vida como trabajadores de atención domiciliaria.
  5. Oportunidades laborales de empleos con mejores salarios. Los empleos directos de atención a largo plazo deberían ofrecer salarios dignos; y, para eso, debemos brindarles a los cuidadores oportunidades laborales para que adquieran más habilidades profesionales y tengan acceso a ofertas de trabajo mejor remunerado en las ramas de atención médica o servicios sociales. Los trabajadores con competencias básicas de atención domiciliaria deberían recibir apoyo para tomar clases de entrenamiento avanzado y acceder a oportunidades laborales en empleos con habilidades más especializadas y mejores salarios
2013: un gran paso para sacar a los cuidadores de la pobreza. Cuando ganamos la lucha por la financiación del contrato de IP y parity, dimos un gran paso para sacar a los cuidadores de la pobreza en el 2013.  Cerca del 25 por ciento de los trabajadores de atención domiciliaria comenzaron a ganar casi $15/hora a partir de julio del 2014. El contrato aumentó los salarios a mínimo $11/hora desde el mes de julio del 2014, y abrió la posibilidad para que los cuidadores con experiencia y entrenamiento avanzado puedan ganar $15/hora. Somos los primeros en la nación en crear una escala salarial que ayuda a estabilizar la fuerza laboral, crear una carrera profesional y ayudar a mejorar la calidad general de los servicios al recompensar la experiencia y el entrenamiento avanzado. Además, en el 2013, logramos otras victorias que nos permiten estar más cerca de cumplir la meta de sacar a los cuidadores de la pobreza, como:
  • Aprobar la expansión de Medicaid en el estado de Washington.  La Affordable Care Act (Ley de atención de salud asequible) mejorará el acceso a la atención médica para miles de cuidadores de bajos ingresos, además de beneficiar a otros miles de cuidadores que ahora cuentan con cobertura de seguro médico gracias a nuestro Health Benefits Trust.
  • Obtener aportes iniciales de jubilación en nuestros contratos de atención domiciliaria con agencias. A pesar de que estos aportes son pequeños y solo entran en vigor al final del ciclo contractual, sientan las bases para obtener un aporte de jubilación en el próximo contrato de IP.
  • La primera clase de aprendices y la primera en obtener un certificado de asistente médico se graduó de la Alianza de Entrenamiento, y representa nuestra primera oportunidad laboral para tener empleos mejor remunerados.  Además, logramos la financiación continua (aunque muy reducida) del entrenamiento avanzado.
  • Conseguimos que se hicieran mejoras significativas en el proceso de Excepción a las Reglas (ETR) para apelar por más horas, con lo cual esperamos que miles de clientes puedan recuperar decenas de miles de horas el próximo año.
  • Redujimos la cantidad de Paid Time Off (tiempo de vacaciones pagadas) de una hora por 40 horas trabajadas a una hora por 35 horas trabajadas.
2014: dimos más pasos para salir de la pobreza. Nos propusimos las siguientes metas como los próximos pasos para que los cuidadores salgan de la pobreza: 1. Salarios
  • Negociamos un nuevo contrato de IP que estipula un aumento para que los salarios de los trabajadores de atención domiciliaria sean de al menos $13/hora desde el mes de julio del 2016.
2. Horas
  • Recuperamos una gran parte de las horas que fueron recortadas desde el año 2009; nuestra meta es recuperar entre $10 y 20 millones (aunque sea presupuesto complementario), lo cual representaría una recuperación de entre el 20 y el 40 por ciento.
  • Mejoramos el registro de atención domiciliaria.
  • Ayudamos a los clientes y a sus proveedores a recuperar horas adicionales a través del proceso de ETR.
  • Si no logramos recuperar una cantidad significativa de horas a través de la legislatura, estudiaremos la forma de someter el tema a una medida de votación.
Un historial de victorias para los cuidadores a largo plazo Durante nuestra primera década:
  • 2001: ganamos el derecho a conformar una unión; la iniciativa 775 fue aprobada por el 63 por ciento de los votantes.
  • 2002: más de 26,000 trabajadores de atención domiciliaria votaron en forma abrumadora a favor de conformar una unión; fue la elección relacionada con uniones más grande de Washington.
  • 2003-2007: ganamos aumentos en los salarios que sumaron más del 40 por ciento, además de seguro médico, compensación para trabajadores, vacaciones pagadas y reembolsos por el uso de vehículos personales para transportar a los clientes.
  • 2006: ganamos parity de salarios para los trabajadores de atención domiciliaria de agencias y más de $20 millones para mejorar los salarios de los nursing homes (asilos para ancianos).
  • 2009-2011: aprobamos dos iniciativas que garantizan el entrenamiento profesional para los trabajadores de atención domiciliaria.
  • Nos hemos convertido en un poderoso defensor legislativo de los cuidadores a largo plazo; el Seattle Times nos comparó con Boeing y Microsoft, y afirmó que “(SEIU 775) ha emergido como uno de los actores más poderosos de Olympia”.  Nuestra defensa es constante; en el 2013, más de 5,000 miembros persuadieron a sus legisladores a través de visitas a sus despachos, llamadas telefónicas, correos electrónicos y/o cartas.
  • Después de cuatro años de luchar contra los recortes durante la Gran Recesión, obtuvimos un nuevo contrato que garantizó los aumentos en el 2013 y el 2014, y un límite superior de casi $15 por hora.

Title: Acerca de nosotros
Content:
Nuestra Unión representa a más de 45,000 trabajadores de atención a largo plazo que brindan atención domiciliaria de calidad, atención en nursing homes (asilos para ancianos) y prestan servicios domiciliarios en Washington y Montana. 

Desde nuestra fundación en el 2002, momento en que nos unimos y comenzamos a hacernos escuchar, los cuidadores han duplicado su salario (y los cuidadores con más experiencia ganan aún más). ¡Pero no vamos a detenernos ahí! Cada vez que regresamos a la mesa de negociación, luchamos por mejores salarios, atención médica, PTO, licencia remunerada por motivos familiares, L&I, jubilación y el derecho de las personas bajo nuestro cuidado a vivir una vida digna.  

Ser parte de nuestra Unión no solo significa que usted disfruta de beneficios; también significa que usted tiene derechos y está representado. Usted tiene derecho a ser representado, sin importar si ha tenido problemas con su salario o ha sido víctima de despidos o acciones disciplinarias injustas al trabajar con el estado de Washington o Montana, una agencia o un nursing home (asilo para ancianos). 

Nuestra Unión es de y para los cuidadores, desde nuestra junta directiva elegida democráticamente, hasta los miembros de nuestros equipos de negociación. Los cuidadores son los que hacen que nuestra Unión sea fuerte.  

Nuestra misión

Nuestra misión es unir las fuerzas de todas las personas trabajadoras y sus familias con el fin de mejorar sus vidas, y marcar el camino hacia un mundo más justo y humanitario.

Más información: 

  • Nuestras prioridades
  • Equipo directivo
  • Noticias
  • Empleo
  • Contacto

Title: Mi Unión: resultados reales
Vincúlese a nuestros programas de pasantías pagadas (MCOI y MMS)
Próximos eventos
Content: Haga clic en los siguientes enlaces para inscribirse en los eventos de SEIU 775 en Washington o Montana. ¡Conozca más acerca de la atención a largo plazo en su área y las formas en que puede defender a los cuidadores!

Title: ¡Comuníquese con sus legisladores!
Content: Dejarles un mensaje a sus legisladores es muy fácil. La línea de atención legislativa lo atenderá durante la legislative session (sesión legislativa), de lunes a viernes, de 8 a. m. a 8 p. m. Antes de llamar, revise su mensaje y asegúrese de lo que quiere decir. Deje un mensaje corto y entendible, y diga específicamente lo que le gustaría que hicieran los legisladores. Pero sobre todo, ¡sea educado! 1. Llame a la línea de atención legislativa: 1.800.562.6000 y dígale a la operadora que le gustaría dejarles un mensaje a sus legisladores. 2. Esté listo para decirle su nombre y dirección al personal de la línea de atención. 3. Ahora podrá dejar un mensaje de correo de voz que será reenviado a su state senator y los dos state representatives. ¡Es así de fácil!
